books.title: Beneath the Darkening Sky
books.author: Majok Tulba
books.description: The rebels measure each boy against an AK47 rifle. Those shorter are left behind. Those taller are taken. Eleven year old Obinna is taller. We feel mankind’s inhumanity brought to life for us through the voice of the boy soldier. The writing is easy to read and beautiful. The content is powerful, gripping, horrific, violent and explicit. This novel is illuminating; as innocence is stripped away what kind of creature do we become?
books.extract: White dust wraps around him as the pebbles dig and dig. The back of his head opens, and it's red for less than a moment before the pieces are painted grey. Each little stone takes a piece of him with it, less and less and less. Landmines don't kill you, they eat you.All this in an instant. Boom! The cloud and pebbles are huge and high, taking up all the air in front of me. Out of the cloud flies a grey dust-painted half-person. One leg and his stomach fly off the road. His left arm sails over my head. The wind from the mine kicks me backwards and I land on another boy
parallels: Song for Night by Chris Abani
Stillness by Courtney Brkic
Lord of the Flies by William Golding

books.title: Disappearing Earth
books.author: Julia Phillips
books.description: Think of a flower: the stem is the crime of the abduction of two sisters and the petals are the lives of residents in the city of Petropavlovsk and town of Kamchatsky who are tentatively involved with the main story. It's written in such a way you feel you're snooping into the lives of others which I find a bit uncomfortable. But a very interesting concept with an intriguing ending – so hang on in there.
books.extract: Some people don't care if you're special. They will punish you anyway. Neighbours, for example, will report a girl, even a smart girl, with a girlfriend. The police will hurt you, if they get the chance. One person up the Okhotsk coast has been burned to death for this only a couple of years earlier. Masha moved away from home at seventeen; when she thought back on life in Kamchatka, she probably pictured volcanoes, tasted caviar, remembered hikes on stone paths to the clouds. She didn't understand what happened these days to girls as innocent as she and Lada had been. They were destroyed for it. Any girl would be. The Golosovsky sisters, who, walking alone, made themselves vulnerable - that one mistake cost them their lives.
parallels: Olive Kitteridge by Elizabeth Strout
Where The Edge Is by Grainne Murphy

books.title: Your Truth or Mine
books.author: Trisha Sakhlecha
books.description: This diary style narrative introduces Mia and her husband Roy and weaves itself around their intimate and familial relationships. Smoke and mirror deceptions emerge as the pacy story gathers momentum across a few short months. Their once seemingly happy lives are laid bare amid a growing tension and sense of foreboding. The revealing of once hidden truths makes the navigation towards acceptance and forgiveness a shocking and dangerous journey.
books.extract: My thoughts circle back . . . I remember being scared. Thinking no one was allowed to be this happy. That something must be wrong. Then cursing myself for thinking it. Forcing myself to be happy. Feel happy. Act happy. Was I role-playing again? I've spent the past few weeks hoping and wishing I could go back in time, fix everything that went wrong, but now I find myself wishing it had never happened.
parallels: Gone Girl by Gillian Flynn
Lies by T.M. Morgan

books.title: The Invisible Guardian
books.author: Dolores Redondo
books.description: In the first of a trilogy, Inspector Salazar returns to her home town Elizondo, near Pamplona, to head the search for a serial killer. So far, so predictable but Salazar is an intriguing character with very good reasons for leaving Elizondo, and I found this a very satisfying blend of police procedural and supernatural thriller, featuring some truly terrifying characters.
books.extract:
Zabalza came back with two printed sheets on which several sentences appeared to have been underlined.
... 'confirms that the officers are linking the case with the recent murders of young girls in the Baztan Valley. The killer slashes their clothes and hairs of non-human origin have been found on the bodies. A terrible lord of the woods who kills within his domain.
parallels: Seeking Whom He May Devour by Fred Vargas
The Frozen Dead by Bernard Minier
I Know Who You Are - TV Series

books.title: Heatstroke
books.author: Hazel Barkworth
books.description: A claustrophobic and gripping read with an intense combination of pace and beauty which really worked for me. As the temperature rises, the threat of collateral damage radiates from every page. This book grabbed my moral certainties and bounced them off the walls. Rachel spoke directly to me - but could I trust her - and what would I have done in her situation - as a mother, as a teacher?
books.extract: The early mornings were different. Seven-thirty could feel like dawn. Pale light would fill the corridors; great shards of light, so perfect their edges could cut, would fall from upper windows. There was peace. The eucalyptus detergent used overnight lingered, masking every other smell that would later taint the place. That morning it felt like a benediction. Rachel inhaled the scent as if it could strip away the terror, the hideous thougths she couldn't fend off; as if it could clean her lungs, cleanse her thoughts, and make everything pure again.
parallels: Appletree Yard by Louise Doherty
Behind Her Eyes by Sarah Pinborough
Amy and Isabelle by Elizabeth Stout

books.title: Blood Orange
books.author: Harriet Tyce
books.description: There is a chilling thread of menace that runs through this book - ratcheting up the tension and unease as the story progresses. You may not like Alison or Patrick or Carl (I didn't) - but I defy you not to be gripped by an addictive narrative that twists and distorts their lives and any understanding of truth. Read at speed - there really isn't any other way.
books.extract:
Patrick goes straight to the kiosk and buys black coffee, pouring something into it from a hip flask that he takes from his briefcase. He doesn't offer me anything and something in his expression makes me reluctant either to question what he's doing or ask if I can join him, even when he lights up a cigarette in direct contravention of the No Smoking signs on the wall. My head's jangling, part of me hoping he'll touch me, drag me into whatever corner he wants and push me face first against the wall and force himself inside me. My mind flits to the text. I take my phone out of my bag and read it again.I know what ur doing u fucking slag.It can't mean this. No one knows about this. We've been so careful. I must be making a mistake that it's been sent to me ...
...I push my phone deep into my jacket pocket, reluctant to discuss the text. If I don't mention it, maybe it'll go away.
parallels: Apple Tree Yard by Louise Doherty
The Secret of Not Drowning by Colette Snowdon
Anatomy of a Scandal by Sarah Vaughan

books.title: The Other Mrs Walker
books.author: Mary Paulson-Ellis
books.description: In this compelling mystery story, the reader becomes the detective, as a grim history of family secrets and thwarted lives spanning the twentieth century is gradually revealed in flashback. Can you piece together the jigsaw of clues and objects from the past, speaking to you beyond the grave, to discover the identity of the old woman in the mortuary?
books.extract:
t was exactly the kind of dingy Edinburgh rental accommodation that she and her mother used to inhabit when Margaret was a girl ... despite a million buckets of Flash, or the yellow squirt of Jif around yet another stained old bath, each flat still contained a thin layer of melancholy, coating everything they touched.
It had taken Margaret a long time to realize that the melancholy didn’t come with the flat. It travelled with her.... It was only when Margaret fled to London and never looked back that she discovered the melancholy didn’t belong to her either. It belonged to her mother instead.
parallels: Elizabeth Is Missing by Emma Healy
What Was Lost by Catherine O'Flynn

books.title: Dear Child
books.author: Romy Hausmann
books.description: reepy thriller about an abduction, partly narrated by a small child - Lisa. In this case the house in the woods is lived in by a male ‘witch’ with a God syndrome - with Lisa is his 'Gretel' victim. Also it is about family values and the power of the media to manipulate people’s opinion of the crime. The voice of the child makes it even more haunting and I finished this in no time.
books.extract:
I lean forwards and make my hands into a secrets funnel. Jonathan and I invented the secrets funnel, but we're not allowed to use it when Papa's at home. Sister Ruth turns her head so that I can put the secrets funnel to her ear.
'She wanted to kill Papa by accident,' I whisper.Sister Ruth's head spins around. Fright, I can see it quite clearly. I shake my head, grab her face and turn it back into the right position for the secrets funnel. 'You don't have to tell the police. Jonathan is taking care of the stains on the carpet.'
parallels: Gone Girl by Gillian Flynn
The Fall - TV series
Like This, For Ever by Sharon Bolton

books.title: Beside Myself
books.author: Ann Morgan
books.description: To fully appreciate this novel the reader is asked to accept that a innocent prank can result in misery and madness and that responsible adults may not appreciate the significance of the joke. Told in the first person by 'Smudge' an identical twin, she describes how the prank results in her descent from delinquency to insanity. Strong characterisation, fast paced, brilliant on family dynamics, extremely disturbing but totally compulsive reading.
books.extract: The sound was coming from the phone receiver dangling next to her. Cautiously she reached for it and held it to her ear. 'Ellie' said the phone, 'it's mother'. And then 'Look, I haven't got time to play silly buggers. I know it's your number ....' 'All right. If that's the way you want it,' continued the phone. 'I'm ringing about Helen'. A sigh. 'Well, there's been an accident and I'm afraid she's in a coma. There. The others thought I should tell you. Left to myself, I probably wouldn't have b-but there we are at least this way you won't hear about it first on the news.' ... Another pause and then angrily, 'Don't you have anything to say?' .... Smudge closed her eyes and took a deep breath. 'I'm afraid you've got the wrong number,'she said, laying the words out one by one like coins on the counter of the offie.
parallels: Repeat it Today With Tears by Anne Peile
The Shock of the Fall by Nathan Filer

books.title: Foster
books.author: Claire Keegan
books.description: A young schoolgirl learns a great deal about families, love and loyalty in 1980's rural Ireland. This novella gave me more to enjoy and to think about in 88 pages than most books can manage in 400.
books.extract: am unused to sitting still and do not know what to do with my hands. Part of me wants my father to leave me here while another part of me wants him to take me back, to what I know. I am in a spot where I can neither be what I always am nor turn into what I could be.
parallels: The Basement Room by Graham Greene
The David Byrnes Stories by -
Room by Emma Donoghue

books.title: The End of Everything
books.author: Megan Abbott
books.description: Thirteen-year old Lizzie and Evie are inseparable until Evie suddenly disappears. Lizzie is convinced their close bond will help solve the mystery, but does Evie's older sister, Dusty, know more than she's letting on? An engrossing, emotional read which took me back to just how it felt during that transitional time when you stop being a little kid and start to get disturbing glimpses of the adult world.
books.extract: One time, the summer before middle school, Evie and I were in my yard long past bedtime, sneaking into a purloined bag of foamy marshmallows and giggling wonderful silent giggles so no one would hear.Dusty and Mr Verver were back there and they had the radio perched on the windowsill and Mr Verver heard an old song he liked and he started singing to it, and it was that kind of singing where you pretend to be making fun of yourself, but you're really loving it. His voice was always like that. Like he just might start laughing at any minute.When the chorus came - 'You don't have to say you love me, just be close at hand' - Dusty started singing too, and her voice was so delicate, like tinkly bells, but she gave it everything and they were having so much fun, stumbling over the words, and we started to know the chorus too, we heard it so many times.
parallels: The Virgin Suicides by Jeffrey Eugenides
The Testament of Jessie Lamb by Jane Rogers
The Lovely Bones by Alice Sebold

books.title: The Vanishing of Katharina Linden
books.author: Helen Grant
books.description: When Katharina Linden vanishes during the Karneval in quiet Bad Munstereifel, ten-year-old Pia imagines it 'seemed like something from a fairy tale'. But the magic quickly turns to horror: Katharina fails to return, two more young girls disappear and a grim pattern emerges from the past to terrify the townspeople. This pacy and suspenseful crossover book will hold readers from nine to ninety spellbound until the final page.
books.extract: The pink hat, ' she said.Suddenly all eyes were upon me. The next second, Frau Mahlberg had stepped forward and with a sharp jerk of her hand had pulled the pink hat from my head, almost taking a handful of hair with it.'Ow,' I said, but nobody heard me. Frau Mahlberg was screaming at the top of her voice, screaming like a stuck pig. She grabbed me by the shoulders and shook me until my teeth chattered. 'She's not Julia! She's not Julia!' she was shrieking, centimetres away from my face.
parallels: A Crime in the Neighbourhood by Suzanne Berne
Sharp Objects by Gillian Flynn
The Last Ride by Thomas Eidson

books.title: Seldom Seen
books.author: Sarah Ridgard
books.description: In this assured debut, we see 1980’s rural Suffolk through the eyes of an angst-ridden teenager. Family feuds and long-buried secrets play out against the backdrop of a changing landscape. A convincing portrayal of life in a small village and a welcome departure from all the twee novels that uphold the rural idyll.
books.extract: Village life wasn't meant to be like this. Where were the fêtes and the babies in bonnets, the village shops and the pubs buzzing with life? Where were all the animals that were meant to be out in the fields? The flower meadows and the kindly old women who snapped open the clasp on their purses to give children a ten pence piece to buy penny chews at the shop? And, good question, where was the shop?
parallels: God's Own Country by Ross Raisin
According to Ruth by Jane Feaver

books.title: Woman of the Dead
books.author: Bernhard Aichner
books.description: 'For me this book adds the excitement of the TV series 'Dexter' to the best puzzle elements of Agatha Christie. The book challenges its reader not only to solve crimes, but also to decide whether murder is ever justified - even by its great main character.
books.extract:
'... How did he die?
''He was run over.
''What happened to driver?
''It was a hit and run. The driver hasn't been traced. He disappeared.'
'- Oh no. Please no.'
'Mark died instantly.''You'd better keep away from me ....
That was no accident.'
parallels: The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo by Stieg Larsson
The Silence of the Sea by Yrsa Sigurdardottir
Curtain by Agatha Christie

books.title: Snake Ropes
books.author: Jess Richards
books.description: 'The Wicker Man' meets the 'Furies' on a remote island, where young boys have started to go missing. But this is no ordinary island. There is a house of horrors that makes Amityville look like child's play, and a level of madness that would make Edgar Allan Poe blanch. A worthy successor to Mary Shelley.
books.extract: Valmarie's kitchen smells of some bitter plant. There's herbs hanging upside down from the beams of the ceiling. Jars stacked along the shelves. One of them is labelled 'Mad Honey - Rhododendron Bees', another has straggly leaves and white flowers tangled inside it and the label says 'Hemlock'. Another says 'Valerian, high concentrate'. I step back and bump into a table where a candle flickers. A root lies on a chopping board, sliced in half. The top half is like a screaming baby's head, but the bottom is the stump of a wizened old man's body.
parallels: The Wicker Man by Robin Hardy
The Bloody Chamber by Angela Carter

books.title: Jackal
books.author: Erin E Adams
books.description: Horror, thriller and fantasy meet in this novel, which kept me awake through the night wanting to see how it would end. Liz, a troubled black woman, visits her nearly all-white birthplace to attend the wedding of her best friend Mel. When Mel’s young daughter disappears, it sets in motion long-forgotten memories of a creature in the woods that abducts and maims little black girls. Tense, page-turning stuff.
books.extract: The violent of the abduction was swift. One moment she was there, the next she was gone, In the seconds before she was dragged into the trees, she still wasn't afraid. She'd reached past that feeling to findsomething more useful.Hope.She prayed- not that nothing bad would happen. She clung to the hope she'd see daylight again. She'd have a chance to laugh with her friends again. She'd see her family. Whispers of these desires escaped her lips. With each one that did, his grip on her grew tighter. When her shoulder gave in a painful pop, she cried out. He looked back at her. He witnessed her pain with curiosity. Like it had never occurred to him she could feel the sensation at all.Beyond this disconnect, Morgan saw him. Sadness morphed into apathetic hate: He made his misery hers. That was when Morgan felt true fear. She didn't need to be an adult to know that sad men are the most dangerous
parallels: The Invisible Guardian by Dolores Redondo
The Nickel Boys by Colson Whitehead
The Outsider by Stephen King

books.title: All the Little Bird-Hearts
books.author: Viktoria Lloyd-Barlow
books.description: Autistic mother Sunday lives with her teenage daughter, Dolly, in a small cottage in the Lake District. When outwardly polished and seemingly charming couple, Vita and Rollo, come to live next door, Dolly and Sunday soon come under their spell. I loved the brooding atmosphere in the book, as much as the voice of Sunday who is brutally honest telling the story.
books.extract: I was engulfed by her. I was held up weightlessly within her gaze, exactly as I had once floated in the cold, dark lake with my sister. It was a sensation like safety. But Vita was still talking: to come with me? I suppose you're, urn, working?' Vita said 'working' as if it was a foreign and unfamiliar word that required concentration for correct pronunciation.'Yes. But I would rather work than go shopping with you.'Her gaze was still fixed on me, but she remained silent for a time, and I noticed the break in her pattern of speech. So far, she had only taken brief pauses in her speech when she specifically wanted a response, and her words were like early fireworks: -tuh -tuh -tuh -tuh -tuh -tuh -tuh -silence tuh tuh tuh tuh tuh tuh tuh tuh silence. I wondered if anyone had ever refused this charming woman anything before. Then she smiled and clapped her hands together like a starlet in a silent film.'Oh, I fucking love that. I love honest people, darling. It's so much easier to say what you think, isn't it? I bet there isn't much of that here, though, is there? Everyone in these little towns is so polite. Inside their little houses. So concerned with what other people think.'
parallels: The Maid by Nita Prose
Small Days and Nights by Tishani Doshi
Listening Still by Ann Griffin

books.title: Future Popes of Ireland
books.author: Darragh Martin
books.description: The story spans three decades from 1979 and the visit of Pope John Paul II to the Irish Republic. Granny Doyle is so much in thrall to the Pontiff and filled with religious fervour, that she decides her next grandchild is destined to become the first Irish Pope. The comic brio of the Irish vernacular, with nods to the 'Father Ted' series, belies the tragic elements of this riotous family saga, so you can be sure of plenty of great 'craic' too!
books.extract: Granny Doyle squinted at the video in front of her. 'Ah, you didn't need to be bothering with this nonsense! ... Would you look at the cut of them!' Granny Doyle said, examining the box. 'Yer man Flatley prancing about in leather pants and that one beside him, flailing her arms about like she's drowning! It's a great gladness that Mammy didn't have to see this like!'... John Paul loved the craic and the chat of the porch: the jokes with Mrs Nugent and the challenge of making Mrs McGinty smile and the treat of seeing Granny Doyle happy ... The porch brought insulation, chat that could swaddle her, while she sat quiet enough in the middle, content to pass the day discussing the gall of Fiona Brennan (parading about in poms, as if she invented Irish dancing!) and the cheek of a Divorce Referendum (it couldn't pass!) and the general goodness of John Paul (a great lad, isn't he? John Paul was a great lad, at least in the porch, where he liked to see himself reflected in the eyes of the old ladies, a boy bringing presents to his grandmother, the kind of figure who might one day summon the future through smiles and dry ice, the breaths of audiences stolen clean from their bodies at the sight of such brilliance: a hero.
parallels: The Anatomy School by Bernard MacLaverty
Inishowen by Joseph O'Connor
M for Mammy by Eleanor O'Reilly

books.title: Who is Rich
books.author: Matthew Klam
books.description: Rich is our eponymous narrator and a typical narcissist - charming, manipulative, impulsive and self-serving, but also wittily introspective. The novel combines two staples of modern fiction – a midlife crisis with the usual adulterous relationship, and a literary alter ego to extract useable material from real-life experiences, friends and family. The title also refers to the philosophical question of what we should most value in life.
books.extract: I needed to find someone at this conference, someone who wouldn't harm a married man, or hated being married, or couldn't bear to be alone for three or four days. I didn't have any big strategy here, I liked to flirt. I needed to stay alert every second for a potential alliance in this war against morbidity and death. Were there rules or prohibitions? Some of my colleagues preyed upon the young, their own students, the low-hanging fruit, which struck me as a real character flaw.
parallels: Rabbit is Rich by John Updike
Less by Andrew Sean Greer

books.title: Animals
books.author: Emma Jane Unsworth
books.description: Vulgar, intense, fast and funny this is a hedonistic tale of friendship, drink, drugs and sex. I struggled with the hold that Tyler has over Laura, but found it to be an interesting look at love, growing up at thirty, and what happens when girls behave badly.
books.extract: Once at a boutique music festival, I’d been walking along with Tyler when she emitted a neat curve of projectile vomit onto the grass in front of her and just carried on walking, resuming what she was saying exactly where she’d left it, barely missing a beat. I don’t think she’d even wiped her mouth. It was an adept expulsion - not so impressive for the twenty people sitting at picnic benches outside a food stand, wooden cutlery held aloft, unable to finish their falafel. We’d christened it the ‘walk and puke’. It was the epitome of styling out. I wasn’t up to it. All I wanted to do was lie down.
parallels: How to be a Woman by Caitlin Moran
Girls - TV Series

books.title: In at the Deep End
books.author: Kate Davies
books.description: Wickedly witty and unflinchingly graphic, this lesbian coming-out odyssey is both eye-opening and eye-watering regarding the sexual exploits of its ingenue protagonist. Think ‘Fleabag’ rather than ‘Bridget Jones’ and you will get the right idea...
books.extract: In my imagination, I was experimental, confident, uninhibited, a biter of shoulders, a user of words like ‘pussy’. I could think about sex in the filthiest terms and speak frankly about it to friends – but when it came to actually doing it, or talking to someone I might do it with, I clammed up. I struggled to think of myself as sexy when I was with another person. I struggled to say sexy things with a straight face. It all felt performative to me, ridiculous, too far removed from the way I behaved in a non-sexy context, like I was playing a part in a porn film, and playing it badly. I couldn’t even flirt convincingly, certainly not when I was sober. Which might go some way towards explaining why it had been so long since I’d fucked anyone.
parallels: Normal People by Sally Rooney
Wetlands by Charlotte Roche

books.title: The Lives of Others
books.author: Neel Mukherjee
books.description: Calcutta 1967. Impelled by their character flaws and their culture, the middle-class Ghoshes slide inexorably to their mutually assured destructions. Utterly compelling and almost completely, horribly, tragic.
books.extract: The knowledge makes her even angrier, but a secret anxiety, just beginning to whisper inside her head leaches it away somewhat: does she ... could she know?Purnima fires her final shots. 'I'm telling you this now, this is your last chance to come to a settlement, otherwise I'll have walls erected to divide the house.'A common enough story in joint families, the threat has not been defanged by the frequency of its occurrence; it curdles and slows the hot flow of anger....
parallels: Noon by Aatish Taseer
Death of a Salesman by Arthur Miller
Bleak House by Charles Dickens

books.title: Girl
books.author: Edna O'Brien
books.description: A harrowing tale, based on true accounts of the kidnapping of 276 schoolgirls by jihadist group Boko Haram in 2014. This book shows one young girl’s courage and determination to survive against all the odds whilst battling with her new identity as a mother. This is a violent, forced coming of age story, told with a shocking detachment and a terrible growing understanding of people and power.
books.extract: But I wanted to speak, to say, Sir you are only a few feet away from me, but you are aeons away from them in their cruel captivity. You have not been there. You cannot know what was done to us. You live by power and we by powerlessness. I thought of my friends at that very moment, under the tamarind tree, some maimed from the bombardment, some newly pregnant, insects feeding feverishly on them, mouthing the same prescribed prayers. My aide guessed my agitation and was telling me to sit still and show good behaviour.
parallels: The Chibok Girls: The Boko Haram Kidnappings and Islamist Militancy in Nigeria by Helon Habila
How We Disappeared by Jing-Jing Lee
Down by the River by Edna O’Brien

books.title: Out
books.author: Natsuo Kirino
books.description: Set in modern Japan, this is a tense and compelling read. It tells the tale of four ordinary working-class women and the profound effect that one event has on their lives. At first glance I didn't think I would enjoy this book but I was totally wrong - I was hooked from the first page and couldn't put it down.
books.extract: She knew now that his hatred was on the verge of erupting, and that he seemed to be enjoying the game of pushing it toward the brink. She had seen the amusement in his eyes, seen how much pleasure it gave him to play cat and mouse with her. But she'd also seen that something in him was unhinged and impelling him towards an explosion. That same thing was inside her, too. It was the part of her that had secretly thought she might be willing to die as long as he were the one to kill her.
parallels: In the Miso Soup by Ryu Murakami
Water Lily by Susanna Jones

books.title: Thirty Girls
books.author: Susan Minot
books.description: Esther is one of 139 schoolgirls abducted by warlord Joseph Kony and forced to become a child soldier. Though she eventually returns home she must then attempt to reconcile herself with all that she has seen, done, and suffered. Told in parallel we learn of Jane, an American writer who goes to Africa to find herself after her marriage fails. Minot weaves their stories together to examine suffering and loss in a suspenseful, heart-rending novel.
books.extract: It is strange to be back. When I was with the rebels I stayed calm inside while there was much suffering around me. Now where it is safe here I am full of anger. Maybe I will nearly explode. I could even pick up a gun and kill someone, I think. I would not do it, but I still do not so much care if I am good anymore or not. In these times it feels good to hate.
parallels: Half of a Yellow Sun by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
Things Fall Apart by Chinua Achebe
A Sunday at the Pool in Kigali by Gil Courtemanche

books.title: Capital
books.author: John Lanchester
books.description: London is a global village, and what brings the international residents of Pepys Road together is perhaps capital in the other sense - money: its tyranny over emotions, talents, lives. The sub-theme of the 'We Want What You Have' conspiracy adds depth and will keep you well and truly gripped until the last page.
books.extract: Having a house in Pepys Road was like being in a casino in which you were guaranteed to be a winner. If you already lived there, you were rich. If you wanted to move there, you had to be rich. It was the first time in history this had ever been true. Britain had become a country of winners and losers, and all the people in the street, just by living there, had won. And the young man on the summer morning moved along the road, filming this street full of winners.
parallels: A Week in December by Sebastian Faulks
Solar by Ian McEwan
Hearts and Minds by Amanda Craig

books.title: Ordinary Thunderstorms
books.author: William Boyd
books.description: The anonymity and vastness of London is the powerful setting for this novel. Although a thriller, it conveys the utter hopelessness of life on the streets for the thousands. The story introduces us to a feral existence and Adam's ability to survive and remain hidden from a ruthless killer is ingenious. A well-written and fast paced story that will grip you until the final page.
books.extract: But there was something about London that he needed, he realised, something basic and fundamental: he needed its size, its great sprawling scale, its millions of denizens, the utter and protective anonymity it provided. He thought about the 600 people a week that went missing in this country, the boys and girls, the men and women who walked out of their front doors, closing them behind them, knowing they would never return, or who climbed out of back windows and ran off into the night to join that vast population of living ghosts that were The Missing.
parallels: Sweetwater : A DI Christy Kennedy Mystery by Paul Charles
Lost From View : Missing Persons in the UK by Nina Biehal

books.title: Outline
books.author: Rachel Cusk
books.description: One to read slowly and turn over in your mind. The narrator, a writer, relates conversations with a wide range of people on how we construct the narratives of our lives, our identity, our relationships. She, herself, remains an enigma.
books.extract: It was interesting to consider ... that a story might merely be a series of events we believe ourselves to be involved in, but on which we have absolutely no influence at all. He himself had noticed nothing on his journey here: he habitually did not notice things which did not concern him, for that very reason, that he saw the tendency to fictionalise our own experiences as positively dangerous, because it convinced us that human life had some kind of design and that we were more significant than we actually were.
parallels: Hotel World by Ali Smith
Search for Time Lost by Marcel Proust

books.title: Yellow Dog
books.author: Martin Amis
books.description: Will Xan Meo stay true to his wish to be a 'new' man - or will thousands of years of caveman conditioning prevail? The England of Martin Amis's blackly comic parallel universe is frighteningly recognisable and I'm very glad I visited it. Though I certainly hope we aren't going to have to live there.
books.extract: 'Charlton? They're crap.''Car's crap. So's Charlton. He's crap and they're crap.''Car's crap. But Charlton aren't that crap.''Bullshit. They're less crap than he is but they're still crap.''Boys, boys: you've got to learn some new swearwords. Take crap, say. I mean bullshit actually means something. Something fairly complicated. Something like: rubbish intended to deceive. But crap? Crap just means crap. As a word, crap is so crap.''That's the whole point of it. Crap's wicked.'
parallels: About a Boy by Nick Hornby
Not the End of the World by Christopher Brookmyre

books.title: Djinn Patrol on the Purple Line
books.author: Deepa Anappara
books.description: The disappearance of children is investigated by 9 yr old Jai and two pals who live in a ‘basti’ (communal village) near a railway line in India. Beautiful descriptions of the ever changing weather and light, the noise and the smells, especially of food as the children are always hungry. Very funny despite the dangers the children face and the horrors that unfold. A brilliant debut novel long listed for the Women’s Prize 2020. I loved it.
books.extract: I look at our house with upside-down-eyes and count five holes in the roof. There might be more, but I can’t see them because the black smog outside has wiped the stars off the sky. I picture a djinn crouching down on the roof, his eyes turning like a key in a lock as he watches us through a hole, waiting for Ma and Papa and Runi-Didi to fall asleep so that he can draw out my soul. Djinns aren’t real, but if they were, they would only steal children because we have the most delicious souls.
parallels: Gachar Gochqar by Vivek Shanbag
The Collector of Words by Iliya Troyanov

books.title: Infinite Home
books.author: Kathleen Alcott
books.description: A tender story of the tenants and owner of a New York brownstone. Despite their frailties, life experiences and medical problems they evoke kindness to each other with words and actions which are extremely touching. It is a perfect example of karma: be kind to others and they will be kind to you. This novel highlights that there are things to be positive about in this world and if we were all a little kinder would this make it a better place?
books.extract: en minutes later, Edward had arranged Edith on his chest and bent his knees in preparation for the first step down. He had determined that nothing was broken, but she refused to ambulate on her own, had remained bubbling the beginnings of sentences from her prone position in his entryway. His left arm cradled the blues and purples of her legs, and his right tensed against her shoulder blades. Her hat, which he had placed back on her head, obstructed his view as he felt his way down the steps, and her breath sounded in strained puffs from her unevenly pink-frosted lips. She began to sing.Pardon me boy, is that the Chattanooga Choo-choo?Right on track twenty-nine, boy can you give me a shine?
parallels: Proximal Alphabets by Kathleen Alcott
Various Pets Alice and Dead by Marina Lewycka

books.title: The Rabbit Factor
books.author: Antti Tuomainen
books.description: This book sets off at pace and doesn't let up throughout as our reluctant hero desperately tries to stay one step ahead of some very nasty people. A clever and surprising tale told with warmth and humour even while an ever-present threat of violent clings to the main characters - and you won't be able to put it down!
books.extract: The dual scent of Laura Helanto and the cinnamon buns. Laura with her bushy hair and large, dark-rimmed glasses on the other side of the table, the cinnamon buns the size of dinner plates in the middle. The coffee maker is gurgling away, and I’ve got my work cut out trying to control myself. For some reason, I feel the need to explain why I have slept this late, that this wasn’t a trivial matter of oversleeping. That the real reason is that I saved my skin by the shores of a dark pond with ten thousand euros, half of which – a down payment – I took from an ATM in the wall of a large hypermarket I’d never seen before, and that I was already tired from lack of sleep the night before when, in self-defence, I killed a man with the enormous rabbit’s ear, which you described as especially ‘unpredictable’, and because dragging the man’s body into the freezer in the café’s kitchen was a two-hour operation requiring raw physical exertion. Instead, I remain quiet, raise a hand to check my tie is straight and notice that my hand is trembling.
parallels: Sick Puppy by Carl Hiaasen
A Man With One of Those Faces by Ciamh McDonnell

books.title: How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia
books.author: Mohsin Hamid
books.description: On the surface, this is the archetypal rags to riches, boy meets girl story, but it is also a vividly honest morality tale and social satire. Written in the second person and historical present, the author draws 'you', the reader, into the unfolding drama, with its pretence of being a motivational 'get-rich' guide. It has the effect of being totally involving, cleverly undermining any preconceptions about the 'otherness' of a foreign culture.
books.extract: Your city is enormous, home to more people than half the countries in the world, to whom every few weeks is added a population equivalent to that of a small, sandy-beached tropical island republic …. A limited access road is under construction around the place, forming a belt past which its urban belly is already beginning to bulge …. Your bus barrels along in the shadow of these monuments, dusty new arteries feeding this city, which despite its immensity is only one among many such organs quivering in the torso of rising Asia.
parallels: The White Tiger by Aravind Adiga
Bright Lights, Big City by Jay McInerney

books.title: Fish Change Direction in Cold Weather
books.author: Pierre Szalowski
books.description: It’s an ill wind, as they say, that blows no good, but this time an ice storm does even more: mending a broken marriage, healing neighbourly rifts and generally acting as a ploy by Cupid – even for fish! This whimsical tale is a cheerful tonic for those cold wintry days, when Spring still seems a long way off.
books.extract: 'Want to play Monopoly?'When was the last time I played Monopoly with my dad?'Come on, come and play with us!'When was the last time I’d played Monopoly with both of them? Probably never. In my mother’s opinion it wasn’t educational enough.'It’s just capitalism dressed up as a game! Wouldn’t Trivial Pursuit be better?'With my hands in casts Trivial Pursuit isn’t very practical.'I could tell my mum was wondering if it was really my dad sitting across from her.'Yes, Dad’s right, I’d rather play Monopoly. All three of us.I put on my whiny little voice, the one from back when I used to try and charm my mum in order to get my way. Dad gestured towards me with his casts as if I were the bearer of some universal truth. My mum sat down. She’d surrendered. But she still had to have the last word.'All right, but not for long!'
parallels: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time by Mark Haddon
Dona Nicanora's Hat Shop by Kirstan Hawkins
The Marriage Bureau for Rich People by Farahad Zama

books.title: The Bookish Life of Nina Hill
books.author: Abbi Waxman
books.description: Nina and her cat Phil made me contemplate my life as a thirty-something living in a city a little less hipster than LA. She is, as was I, fond of her easy life as a bookish person, with her friends and her pub-quiz team. Until a long lost dead father turns her life around, gives her siblings and a boyfriend she doesn't want. What more can I want as a reader, lusting for something funny, light and airy as a chocolate cupcake with a bit of chili?
books.extract: 'You're a craven coward and wouldn't even emerge to defend your second favorite nineteenth-century writer. For shame.'Liz shrugged. 'Ms. Austen needs no defense. You did fine, and besides, I've never forgotten a long conversation I had with that particular customer about LSD and the boundaries of consciousness.' She straightened some copies of Roller Girl. 'I thought I was asking about her vacation, but it turned out she'd stayed home and gone further than she ever thought possible.' She tipped her head down to peer at Nina over her glasses, her short, dark hair barely touched with gray, despite the several careers she'd had, and the many cities and lives she'd been part of. 'There was a long portion about the deep inner beauty of yogurt when viewed through the lens of hallucinogens that put me off Yoplait for life.'Nina regarded her carefully. 'I find that story almost impossible to believe.'Liz turned and walked toward non-fiction. 'I should hope so, seeing as I completely made it up.'
parallels: High Fidelity by Nick Hornby
The Bookshop on the Shore by Jenny Colgan
Notting Hill - the film

books.title: Various Pets Alive and Dead
books.author: Marina Lewycka
books.description: This is a very funny book about family and ethics. Amid the global financial crisis, Doro sets out to tell her grown up children some good news. But each is preoccupied with a crisis of their own: Serge, putting their commune childhood behind him, is making good money in banking but can't face telling Doro. Oolie-Anna wants to leave home. And Clara, teaching in a difficult school, has to confront past demons in the form of a class hamster.
books.extract: Now let's jumble up these risks and repackage them. Let's put together a bundle which includes, say, the lightning strike, him and Maroushka in bed, and Chicken having a heart attack. The chances of them all happening are still pretty low, because of the lightning strike. But if you take out the lightning strike, what are you left with? Serge hasn't a clue - and the truth is, neither have most people who trade in risk-based derivatives.
parallels: A Long Way Down by Nick Nornby
My Fat Brother by Jim Keeble
The Full Monty - the film

books.title: Domestic Bliss and Other Disasters
books.author: Jane Ions
books.description: Sally tells the story of her mid-life antics involving her 'creative' son, her overwhelmed new-mum daughter, her politician spouse, a rat-catching lodger, two long-standing friends, and a neighbour with an unhealthy interest in rhubarb leaves. Sally's life is all wrapped up in a comical coat of witty observation and good old-fashioned British humour guaranteed to raise a smile (and an eyebrow).
books.extract: After almost an hour of this mental turmoil I was friendless, ancient, toothless, gorged on chocolate, unable to remember how to drive my car, in prison and facing Armageddon. Then it occurred to me for the very first time that my husband was called Bill and my son-in-law was called Ben and my whole life felt absurd.
parallels: Super Host by Kate Russo
Did the Earth Move? by Carmen Reid
Things My Mother Told Me by Tanya Attapattu

books.title: What You Don't Know
books.author: David Belbin
books.description: Prepare to be addicted to this pulse-racing thriller, where drugs and politics make for uneasy bedfellows. Nick and Sarah's seemingly separate worlds become intertwined in a way neither of them could have foreseen.
books.extract: Nick went out and lifted the bin, saw the plastic bag. This was what the police had been looking for. The bag was full of paper wraps. There must have been a hundred of them. Nick didn't pick it up. He didn't want to get his fingerprints on it. He knew what would be inside. Crack cocain. Ten pound wraps. Over a grand's worth. Enough to put him back inside and give him a new sentence the same length as the old one.
parallels: N-W by Zadie Smith
The Girl who Kicked the Hornet's Nest by Steigg Larsson

books.title: The Terror of Living
books.author: Urban Waite
books.description: In this modern western thriller, drug trafficking replaces the old Wild-West gunslinger and cattle-rustling themes, with an ex-convict drugs-runner pursued by the lawmen and a psychopathic hit-man. You will need a strong stomach to cope with all the blood-letting, as here the villains are nastier, the killings grislier - and with no moral certainties any more, whose side will you be on?
books.extract: A minute passed and then another. The smoke alarm sounded, the smell of something burning. Nora heard footsteps go past. Something hit the floor hard outside her door, shaking the wooden boards. She heard a man's voice call out, and then nothing else. Nora didn't dare to move. There was no sound now, just Nora sitting in a pitch-black room with only the sliver of light entering from beneath the door. She waited. Something dark and liquid began to creep beneath her door. She knew already what it was, the light slowly disappearing as the blood spread out along the floorboards.
parallels: No Country for Old men by Cormac McCarthy
Tourist in the Yucatan by James McNay Brumfield
Fargo - the film

books.title: A Possibility of violent
books.author: D A Mishani
books.description: Some crime novels you are there, right in the thick of it, living and breathing every move of the detective. But this book is different and it's that difference that's so compelling. Inspector Avraham comes across as an reluctant detective, maybe jaded, doing the job because he's good at it. Reading it I felt as though I was watching the story unfold through one-way glass in the room next door.
books.extract: Had he already known when he woke up that the reason for the trip wasn't only to avoid the police's interrogation? The questioning at the station had scared him less the day after. When he had left the station, his hands trembled on the car's steering wheel, but since he had started carrying out the plan, the shaking had ceased. He was frightened not because of the questions the detective had posed to him but rather because of those he had not. And he had no reason to panic. At night he'd spoken with Chava Cohen and the conversation had gone well. The investigation had certainly turned away from him, or would do so in the days to come. He could have cancelled the trip - and in retrospect, if he had cancelled it, it was possible he wouldn't have been caught - but he already wanted to get away for other reasons.
parallels: Roseanna by Maj Sjowall & Per Wahloo
The Hanged Man of Saint-Pholien by Georges Simenon

books.title: Seventy Times Seven
books.author: John Gordon Sinclair
books.description: 1992 and the Troubles are far from over - in Alabama USA as well as in Northern Ireland. A gripping, violent, complicated plot makes this book a great thriller, but it also raises interesting questions regarding inherent evil and the problems caused by personal revenge.
books.extract: But worst of all, a head shorn at the neck: the face partially covered by long matted strips of hair and caked with dried blood; the drawn, colourless skin stretched tight over its skull.          Danny stared at the head in horror, unable to break away. Suddenly every muscle in his body contracted at the same instant, as a terrible realisation left him struggling to catch his breath.
parallels: The Salesman by Joseph O'Connor
All the Colours of the Town by Liam McIlvanney

books.title: Anansi Boys
books.author: Neil Gaiman
books.description: Enter the completely insane world of Fat Charlie Nancy and his family, friends and enemies. Suspend your disbelief, marvel at murderous theatrical agents, ghosts, a godlike father, a sort of imaginary brother, and remember that the spiders have all the stories.
books.extract: Daisy looked at him with the kind of expression that Jesus might have given someone who had just explained that he was probably allergic to bread and fishes, so could He possibly do him a quick chicken salad.
parallels: Wintersmith by Terry Pratchett
The Mabinogion by Anon
Dreamsongs by George R R Martin

books.title: The Glass Books of the Dream Eaters
books.author: W G Dahlquist
books.description: This is a gothic fantasy thriller packaged in a big, big book. So set some time aside for it because I guarantee you won't be able put it down. A sort of 'Fingersmith' meets 'Frankenstein' with touches of black humour that are entirely 21st century.
books.extract: She had known other men with such open capacity for brutal action - in fact, her father was just such a man - but there the brutality had always been clothed in the guise of business and friendship. With Chang, the truth of the work was worn openly. She struggled to find this refreshing - she told herself it was exactly that - but could not suppress a shudder. Doctor Svenson seemed to her less formidable and more stricken by common fears and hesitancies, but then so was she - and Miss Temple knew that no one in her world would have granted her the capacity to survive what she already had. She trusted in the Doctor's resilience then, as she trusted in her own. Besides, she smiled to think it, many otherwise capable men were not at their best around a fetching woman.
parallels: The End of Mr Y by Scarlett Thomas
The Meaning of Night by Michael Cox
The Somnambulist by Jonathan Barnes

books.title: The Taker
books.author: Alma Katsu
books.description: An epic debut tale of immortality with the obsessive love affair between Lanny and Jonathan at its heart. The mesmerising, strange and compelling story moves effortlessly from past to present spanning two centuries and two continents with scenes of brutality, magic and decadence along the way. One to keep you up at night and be glad that it is not possible to live forever!
books.extract: She lifts her chest, arms outstretched, as though to give him a better view, but Luke can see fine, only he can't believe what he is seeing. The two sides of the cut are creeping towards each other like the tendrils of a plant, rejoining, knitting together. The cut has stopped bleeding and is starting to heal. Through it, the girl's breathing is rough but she betrays no sense of pain. Luke can't be sure his feet are on the floor. He is watching the impossible - the impossible!
parallels: Incubus by Carol Goodman
Incubus by Carol Goodman

books.title: A Madness of Angels
books.author: Kate Griffin
books.description: Vibrant and exhilarating urban fantasy: there's an undercurrent of sheer joy to Matthew Swift's quest for the shadow that hunts him. Kate Griffin has the sorcerer's gift of seeing life in overlooked places. I'll never feel the same way about pigeons and automatic telephone menus again! And, I'm looking forward to reading the sequel, 'The Midnight Mayor'.
books.extract: I ducked. I can respect a formidable magical talent when I meet it, and Old Madam Dorie, the greI ducked, which is why the bullet from the sniper's rifle shattered the skull of the horse-faced man, who'd just been standing, rather than mine.
parallels: Neverwhere by Neil Gaiman
Jonathan Strange and Mr Norrell by Susanna Clarke

books.title: The Summer of Impossible Things
books.author: Rowan Coleman
books.description: With echoes of the film 'Back to the Future', this particular time-travelling journey of discovery takes us back to the Seventies era with its disco music, drugs and sexual freedom. A family drama, combining romance and SF - plus themes of depression, alcoholism and drug addiction does not sound like a feel-good read, but the overall mood is uplifting. An ideal read for book clubs.
books.extract: Love outlasts even death. It's present in every moment, even those filled with darkness; its never exhausted, it never gives up or wavers. It's the one force of the universe that will never be captured by an equation or your science.
parallels: The Time Traveler's Wife by Audrey Niffenegger
The Light Between Us by Katie Kahn

books.title: The Invisible Library
books.author: Genevieve Cogman
books.description: Irene is on a mission for the mysterious organisation The Library whose aim is to travel worlds collecting important books. With a new trainee in tow, danger and intrigue at every turn, dragons, mechanical creatures, fae, and a sinister ex-Librarian to contend with, Irene’s quest in this steam-punk London is not going to be easy. This is an engaging, intriguing, and exciting first title in a new series where getting the book is everything.
books.extract: It hit her like a whiplash across her back, throwing her to her knees on the dirty pavement. She could feel every inch of her Library tattoo burning, feel it mapped out across her back as clearly as if she could see it. The world shivered around her. She tasted bile in her mouth, and struggled not to throw up.The words were everywhere. She could see them on the newspaper stands, swimming up through the whiteness to crawl across the paper. She could see them on the back of the paperback novel which the man in front of her had tucked into his pocket, on the crudely printed advertisements fluttering from every stall and on the receipts which the woman to her left was checking. They printed themselves on everything legible in a spreading circle around her.BEWARE ALBERICH.
parallels: The Masked City by Genevieve Cogman
The Eyre Affair by Jasper Fforde
The Watchmaker of Filigree Street by Natasha Pulley

books.title: Escape Routes
books.author: Naomi Ishiguro
books.description: I loved these surreal and quirky short stories. Naomi Ishiguro has the knack of making the dream-like seem remarkably normal and feasible.
books.extract: When I arrived back on that particular rat-catching day, the sack containing the two palace beasts over my shoulder, I found myself appreciating my rooms to a greater extent than usual. I supposed that it must have been something to do with having had the opportunity of comparing them to the residence of a king, only to find I liked my own home far better, and I laughed aloud at that idea as I settled back into my humble, orderly home again. I ran my fingers over my workbench, with its neat lines of hammers and nails and pliers and saws and sandpaper, all stacked up in a most orderly arrangement. I surveyed the corner that served as my sleeping area, and continued to feel glad and so confident, so cheerful at being home, until I looked over towards the mirror and I found my mood turning almost melancholy to think that I was the only person there to appreciate all that perfection. Just myself and the rats. An enviable party.
parallels: Long Story Short by Jodi Taylor
Bryant and May London’s Glory by Christopher Fowler
Tales from the Folly by Ben Aaronovitch

books.title: The Peculiar Life of a Lonely Postman
books.author: Denis Thériault
books.description: What a surprising little book this is and quite hard to pigeonhole. I could not condone the actions of a postman who steams open the letters he intercepts. But my unease was swept away by the beautiful haiku and tanka that form part of the story - simply sublime.
books.extract: The letters from the Guadeloupean woman contained nothing else. Always a single sheet of paper on which was written a single poem. It wasn't much, yet it was generous, since those poems nourished you as much as a whole novel - they were long in your soul, where they echoed forever. Bilodo learned them by heart and recited them to himself on his morning round. He treasured them up in the top drawer of his bedside table and liked spreading them around him at night, constructing a kind of mystical circle, and rereading them one after the other...
parallels: The Guest Cat by Takashi Hiraide
Can't and Won't by Lydia Davis

countries.name: Afghanistan
countries.description: Afghan literature has a rich written and oral tradition, with poetry being its oldest form. It often reflects diverse spiritual traditions, including mystical and Sufi influences.

countries.name: Albania
countries.description: Albanian literature, for centuries suppressed under Ottoman rule, began to flourish in the late 19th century with a focus on national identity and Romanticism. Early works were often religious, but later expanded to include folklore and patriotic themes.

common_books.title: The General of the Dead Army
common_books.author: Ismail Kadare

countries.name: Algeria
countries.description: Algerian literature has ancient roots with diverse cultural influences, predominantly oral traditions. During French colonization, Algerian writers emerged, contributing significantly to world literature, often reflecting the country's struggle for independence, post-colonial identity, and social issues in both Arabic and French.

countries.name: Argentina
countries.description: Argentinian literature is a rich tapestry of narratives, influenced by romanticism and naturalism in the 19th century, and later by innovative storytelling from authors like Jorge Luis Borges and Julio Cortázar. It often explores themes of national identity, social justice, and complex socio-political issues.

countries.name: Australia
countries.description: Australian literature began with early European accounts and evolved to explore themes of Aboriginality, mateship, egalitarianism, democracy, national identity, migration, and the unique Australian landscape. It reflects a distinct national consciousness.

countries.name: Austria
countries.description: Austrian literature boasts a rich tradition from the 19th century onward, with notable novelists and poets like Adalbert Stifter, Arthur Schnitzler, Franz Kafka, Stefan Zweig, and Robert Musil. It often explores psychological depth, philosophical themes, and the complexities of human existence.

countries.name: Bangladesh
countries.description: Bengali literature, shared with West Bengal in India, has a long history dating back to medieval poetic genres including religious scriptures, Islamic epics, Vaishnava texts, and secular works. Modern Bangladeshi literature often reflects the country's unique cultural identity and historical events.

countries.name: Belarus
countries.description: Belarusian literature emerged from Kievan Rus' traditions, gaining a distinct voice in the 14th-15th centuries. Its golden age in the 16th-17th centuries saw works in Old Belarusian. After periods of decline due to foreign cultural dominance, a literary renaissance began in the 19th century, often exploring themes of patriotism and common life.

countries.name: Belgium
countries.description: Belgian literature is unique due to its linguistic divisions, with significant bodies of work in both Flemish (Standard Dutch) and French, as well as Walloon dialects. It has seen movements from Romanticism to Realism, often exploring local scenery, individual psychology, and social commentary.

countries.name: Bolivia
countries.description: Bolivian literature is rich in indigenous and Spanish influences, reflecting the country's diverse cultural heritage. It frequently explores themes of social justice, identity, and the profound impact of colonialism.
countries.official_language: Spanish, Quechua, Aymara, and other indigenous languages

countries.name: Bosnia and Herzegovina
countries.description: The literature of Bosnia and Herzegovina is a complex and multicultural production, often written in Serbo-Croatian, Bosnian, Croatian, and Serbian, and historically in Ladino, Arabic, Persian, and Ottoman-Turkish. It encompasses diverse literary traditions shaped by its unique history and religious influences.
countries.religion: Muslim, Serbian Orthodox, and Roman Catholic

countries.name: Brazil
countries.description: Brazilian literature has significantly contributed to the Latin American literary landscape, exploring themes of identity, inequality, and cultural heritage, from colonial influences to the Modernist movement. Authors like Machado de Assis, Clarice Lispector, and Paulo Coelho have gained international recognition.

common_books.title: The Devil to Pay in the Backlands
common_books.author: João Guimarães Rosa

countries.name: Bulgaria
countries.description: Medieval Bulgarian literature, predominantly religious, saw a golden age in the 9th-11th centuries with translations from Byzantine Greek and original works. It significantly influenced Slavic literature, spreading Old Bulgarian and the Cyrillic script.

countries.name: Canada
countries.description: Canadian literature reflects diverse cultural influences, including Indigenous traditions, French and British colonialism. It has evolved from works mirroring European styles to a distinct national identity, embracing various voices and experiences, often characterized by social consciousness.

countries.name: Chile
countries.description: Chilean literature has a rich tradition, primarily in Spanish, and has been home to Nobel laureates Gabriela Mistral and Pablo Neruda. It began with chronicles of the Spanish conquest and evolved through Romanticism, Criollismo (portraying local customs), and a vibrant Avant-garde movement in the 20th century.

common_books.title: Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair
common_books.author: Pablo Neruda

countries.name: China
countries.description: Chinese literature boasts a continuous tradition of over 3,500 years, encompassing diverse genres like poetry, essays, fiction, and drama. It reflects the social climate of its day and has evolved through classical, modern, contemporary, and present-age periods, often imbued with a strong sense of cultural tradition.

countries.name: Colombia
countries.description: Colombian literature is varied and dynamic, often incorporating strong political and cultural opinions. From early religious works under Spanish rule to the costumbrista movement depicting peasant life and the later modernismo, it reflects the country's history. Nobel laureate Gabriel García Márquez is a globally acclaimed figure.

common_books.title: Love in the Time of Cholera
common_books.author: Gabriel García Márquez

countries.name: Croatia
countries.description: Croatian literature spans from medieval texts to modern works, using various Croatian languages and scripts. It is divided into distinct stylistic formations like Renaissance, Baroque, Romanticism, and Realism, often reflecting national identity and historical periods.

countries.name: Cuba
countries.description: Cuban literature began to find its voice in the early 19th century, with abolitionist themes. After the abolition of slavery, the focus shifted to independence and freedom, notably with José Martí leading the modernista movement. It is one of the most prolific and influential literatures in Latin America.

common_books.title: The Old Man and the Sea
common_books.author: Ernest Hemingway

countries.name: Czech Republic
countries.description: Czech literature, with roots in medieval Christian hymns, expanded to various genres including satire and folklore. Despite facing restrictions under the Habsburg Empire and Soviet regime, it persevered, with a significant revival in the 19th century focusing on Czech history and culture. Notable authors include Franz Kafka and Milan Kundera.
countries.religion: Mostly Roman Catholic, some Protestant (many profess no religious beliefs)

countries.name: Denmark
countries.description: Danish literature is widely recognized for its contributions to children's literature, most famously through Hans Christian Andersen's fairy tales. It also encompasses a rich tradition of philosophical works, realism, and modern thrillers.

common_books.title: The Fairy Tales of Hans Christian Andersen
common_books.author: Hans Christian Andersen

countries.name: Egypt
countries.description: Egyptian literature has a long and rich history, from ancient hieroglyphic texts to modern Arabic literature. Nobel laureate Naguib Mahfouz is a prominent figure, whose works often depict Egyptian society and historical transformations.

countries.name: Ethiopia
countries.description: Ethiopian literature has ancient roots in Ge'ez, Amharic, and Oromo languages, often with religious and historical themes. Contemporary Ethiopian literature explores modern societal issues, historical events, and the diaspora experience.

common_books.title: The Beautiful Things That Heaven Bears
common_books.author: Dinaw Mengestu

countries.name: Finland
countries.description: Finnish literature is deeply rooted in its folklore and national epic, the Kalevala. Modern Finnish literature often features themes of national identity, nature, and the country's unique history, with authors like Mika Waltari gaining international acclaim for historical fiction.

countries.name: France
countries.description: French literature is one of the most influential in the Western world, spanning centuries of movements like Romanticism, Realism, Symbolism, and Existentialism. It boasts literary giants such as Victor Hugo, Alexandre Dumas, Gustave Flaubert, and Marcel Proust.

countries.name: Germany
countries.description: German literature has a profound impact on world culture, with a rich history spanning from medieval epics to the Enlightenment, Romanticism, and 20th-century modernism. Key figures include Goethe, Thomas Mann, and Günter Grass, often exploring philosophical, historical, and social themes.

common_books.title: All Quiet on the Western Front
common_books.author: Erich Maria Remarque

countries.name: Greece
countries.description: Greek literature is one of the oldest and most influential in the Western world, originating from ancient epic poetry like Homer's Odyssey, and foundational works of philosophy and drama. Modern Greek literature continues to explore themes of identity, history, and human condition.

countries.name: Hungary
countries.description: Hungarian literature has a rich history, often reflecting the nation's tumultuous past and cultural identity. It encompasses a wide range of genres, from historical novels and poetry to works exploring existential themes and the impact of major historical events.

countries.name: Iceland
countries.description: Icelandic literature is renowned for its medieval sagas, which are significant historical and literary works. Modern Icelandic literature continues to draw on its unique cultural heritage, often featuring themes of nature, isolation, and the human struggle.

countries.name: India
countries.description: Indian literature is one of the world's oldest and most diverse, with traditions in numerous languages. It encompasses ancient epics like the Mahabharata and Ramayana, classical poetry, and modern works that explore postcolonial identity, social issues, and magical realism.
countries.religion: Hinduism, Islam, Christianity, Sikhism, Buddhism, Jainism

countries.name: Indonesia
countries.description: Indonesian literature reflects the nation's diverse ethnic groups and colonial history. It often explores themes of identity, social change, and the struggle for independence, with authors like Pramoedya Ananta Toer being internationally recognized for their historical fiction.

countries.name: Iran
countries.description: Iranian literature, particularly Persian literature, is one of the world's oldest and most influential, known for its rich poetic tradition exemplified by Ferdowsi's Shahnameh and Omar Khayyam's Rubaiyat. Modern Iranian literature continues to explore social and political themes, often through the lens of memoir and graphic novels.

countries.name: Iraq
countries.description: Iraqi literature has ancient roots in Mesopotamia, home to the Epic of Gilgamesh, one of the earliest surviving works of literature. Modern Iraqi literature often reflects the country's complex political landscape and social challenges, with a growing body of work in various genres.

countries.name: Ireland
countries.description: Irish literature is world-renowned for its rich tradition of storytelling, poetry, and drama, producing literary giants like James Joyce, W.B. Yeats, Samuel Beckett, and Bram Stoker. It often explores themes of national identity, history, mythology, and social commentary.

countries.name: Israel
countries.description: Israeli literature, primarily in Hebrew, often grapples with themes of national identity, historical memory, conflict, and the complexities of modern Israeli society. Authors like Amos Oz have gained international recognition for their poignant narratives.

common_books.title: A Tale of Love and Darkness
common_books.author: Amos Oz

countries.name: Italy
countries.description: Italian literature has a profound and enduring legacy, from Dante Alighieri's 'The Divine Comedy' to the Renaissance and modern movements. It encompasses epic poetry, historical novels, and contemporary fiction that often explores social change and personal relationships.

countries.name: Japan
countries.description: Japanese literature has a long and distinguished history, from classical works like 'The Tale of Genji' to modern masterpieces. It often features themes of nature, aesthetics, philosophical introspection, and the complexities of modern life, with authors like Natsume Sōseki and Haruki Murakami gaining global recognition.

countries.name: Kenya
countries.description: Kenyan literature, primarily in English and Swahili, often explores themes of colonialism, post-independence challenges, cultural identity, and social justice. Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o is a prominent figure known for his critiques of colonial legacies.

countries.name: Mexico
countries.description: Mexican literature is a vibrant and diverse tradition, deeply influenced by indigenous cultures, Spanish colonialism, and revolutionary movements. It encompasses magical realism, philosophical essays, and narratives exploring national identity and social issues, with authors like Juan Rulfo and Octavio Paz.

countries.name: Morocco
countries.description: Moroccan literature is characterized by its multilingual nature, with works in Arabic, Berber, and French. It often explores themes of identity, tradition, modernity, and the complexities of postcolonial society, with authors like Tahar Ben Jelloun gaining international acclaim.

common_books.title: The Secret of the Sacred Name
common_books.author: Mohamed Choukri

countries.name: Netherlands
countries.description: Dutch literature has a rich history, from medieval texts to the Golden Age and modern works. It often explores themes of personal experience, societal norms, and historical events, with notable contributions like Anne Frank's diary and philosophical novels.

common_books.title: The Diary of a Young Girl
common_books.author: Anne Frank

countries.name: New Zealand
countries.description: New Zealand literature is deeply influenced by its unique landscape, Māori culture, and colonial history. It often explores themes of identity, belonging, and the relationship between people and their environment, with a strong voice in contemporary fiction.
countries.official_language: English, Māori, New Zealand Sign Language

countries.name: Nigeria
countries.description: Nigerian literature is a cornerstone of African literature, with a vibrant tradition of storytelling, poetry, and drama. It often addresses themes of colonialism, post-independence challenges, cultural identity, and social justice, with Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka and Chinua Achebe being highly influential figures.

countries.name: Norway
countries.description: Norwegian literature is known for its strong tradition of realism, psychological depth, and exploration of human nature. From Knut Hamsun's existential novels to Jostein Gaarder's philosophical works, it often reflects the country's unique cultural and natural landscapes.

countries.name: Pakistan
countries.description: Pakistani literature, primarily in Urdu and English, often explores themes of partition, national identity, social class, and the complexities of modern Pakistani society. Authors like Mohsin Hamid have gained international recognition for their contemporary fiction.

countries.name: Peru
countries.description: Peruvian literature is deeply rooted in its indigenous heritage and colonial past, evolving through various movements like indigenismo and magical realism. Nobel laureate Mario Vargas Llosa is a prominent figure, known for his political and historical novels that often critique Peruvian society.

countries.name: Philippines
countries.description: Philippine literature reflects its diverse cultural influences, including indigenous traditions, Spanish colonialism, and American occupation. It often explores themes of national identity, social injustice, and the struggle for independence, with works in various languages.

countries.name: Poland
countries.description: Polish literature has a rich and complex history, often intertwined with the nation's struggles for independence and identity. It encompasses epic poetry, historical novels, and modern works that explore philosophical and social themes, with Nobel laureates like Henryk Sienkiewicz and Olga Tokarczuk.

countries.name: Portugal
countries.description: Portuguese literature has a long and distinguished history, from medieval poetry to the Golden Age of exploration and modern movements. It often explores themes of national identity, saudade (a deep emotional state of nostalgic longing), and social critique, with Nobel laureate José Saramago being a prominent figure.

countries.name: Romania
countries.description: Romanian literature has developed through various influences, including Byzantine, Ottoman, and Western European traditions. It often explores themes of national identity, rural life, and the psychological impact of historical events, with a strong emphasis on poetry and prose.

countries.name: Russia
countries.description: Russian literature is world-renowned for its depth, psychological insight, and philosophical themes. It boasts literary giants such as Leo Tolstoy, Fyodor Dostoevsky, and Mikhail Bulgakov, whose works often explore morality, society, and the human condition.

countries.name: Saudi Arabia
countries.description: Saudi Arabian literature is primarily in Arabic and has evolved to reflect the country's rapid modernization and societal changes. It often explores themes of tradition versus modernity, social norms, and individual experiences within a changing landscape.

countries.name: Senegal
countries.description: Senegalese literature is a significant part of Francophone African literature, often exploring themes of colonialism, post-independence identity, and the role of women in society. Mariama Bâ is a notable figure known for her feminist perspectives.

countries.name: Serbia
countries.description: Serbian literature has a rich history, influenced by its position at the crossroads of East and West. It encompasses various genres and movements, often exploring themes of national identity, historical memory, and the complexities of the Balkan region.

countries.name: South Africa
countries.description: South African literature is deeply shaped by its history of apartheid and the struggle for freedom. It often explores themes of racial injustice, reconciliation, identity, and the human spirit, with Nobel laureates like Nadine Gordimer and J.M. Coetzee.
countries.official_language: Afrikaans, English, Ndebele, Pedi, South Sotho, Swazi, Tsonga, Tswana, Venda, Xhosa, Zulu

countries.name: South Korea
countries.description: South Korean literature has gained international prominence, often exploring themes of rapid modernization, societal pressures, family dynamics, and psychological depth. Authors like Han Kang have brought Korean literature to a global audience.

countries.name: Spain
countries.description: Spanish literature has a profound and enduring legacy, from Miguel de Cervantes' 'Don Quixote' to the Golden Age and modern movements. It encompasses satire, adventure, philosophical works, and contemporary fiction that often explores historical memory and societal complexities.

countries.name: Sweden
countries.description: Swedish literature is known for its strong tradition of children's literature, crime fiction, and philosophical novels. Authors like Astrid Lindgren and Stieg Larsson have achieved global success, often exploring societal issues and human nature.

common_books.title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo
common_books.author: Stieg Larsson

countries.name: Switzerland
countries.description: Swiss literature is diverse, reflecting its multilingual nature (German, French, Italian, Romansh). It often explores themes of neutrality, identity, and the complexities of human existence, with notable contributions to children's literature and philosophical drama.

countries.name: Thailand
countries.description: Thai literature has a rich history, deeply rooted in Buddhist traditions and royal chronicles. Modern Thai literature often reflects societal changes, political landscapes, and the interplay between tradition and modernity.

countries.name: Turkey
countries.description: Turkish literature has a vibrant tradition, blending Ottoman influences with modern Turkish identity. Nobel laureate Orhan Pamuk is a leading figure, whose works often explore themes of identity, memory, and the clash between East and West.

countries.name: Ukraine
countries.description: Ukrainian literature has a long and rich history, deeply intertwined with the nation's identity and struggles. It encompasses a strong poetic tradition, historical narratives, and modern works that often explore themes of national consciousness and societal challenges.
countries.religion: Orthodoxy (Ukrainian Orthodox Church – Kyiv Patriarchate, Ukrainian Orthodox Church – Moscow Patriarchate)

countries.name: United Kingdom
countries.description: British literature is one of the most influential in the world, with a rich history spanning from Shakespeare to modern authors. It encompasses a vast array of genres, from classic novels and poetry to dystopian fiction and social commentary, often exploring themes of class, society, and identity.
countries.religion: Christianity (Church of England, Roman Catholic, etc.), No religion

countries.name: United States
countries.description: American literature is diverse and influential, reflecting the nation's varied history, cultures, and landscapes. It encompasses a wide range of genres, from classic novels and adventure stories to social critiques and coming-of-age narratives, often exploring themes of individualism, freedom, and the American Dream.

countries.name: Uruguay
countries.description: Uruguayan literature is known for its strong tradition of short stories and essays, often exploring themes of history, memory, and social commentary. Eduardo Galeano is a globally recognized author for his unique narrative style.

countries.name: Venezuela
countries.description: Venezuelan literature often explores themes of regionalism, political upheaval, and social realities. Rómulo Gallegos is a key figure, known for his regionalist novels that depict the Venezuelan landscape and its people.

countries.name: Vietnam
countries.description: Vietnamese literature has a long history, often reflecting the nation's struggles for independence and cultural identity. Modern Vietnamese literature explores themes of war, its aftermath, and the complexities of contemporary life, with a growing presence on the international stage.

suggest_book.title: Disappearing Earth
suggest_book.author: Julia Phillips
